content:
• The author, Soyeon Ji, a frontend developer at Toss, improved the accessibility of the Toss customer center chatbot.
  • Previously, screen reader users could not perceive screen changes when new messages or buttons appeared in the chatbot, causing them to miss the conversational flow.
  • To address this, the author focused on creating a natural flow for screen reader users by reflecting the visual UI flow in focus movement.
  • This involved ensuring the focus moved to new content when the screen changed, guiding the user through the conversation.
  • A key challenge was the timing of focus movement. Simply using `target.focus()` caused abrupt scrolling, disrupting the smooth auto-scroll feature.
  • The solution involved a two-step process: first smoothly scrolling to the message box using `scrollIntoView({ behavior: 'smooth' })`, and then, after a short delay (around 1 second), moving the focus using `target.focus({ preventScroll: true })` to prevent the focus change from overriding the scroll.
  • Additionally, an auditory cue, "Please select a menu button below," was added for screen reader users to inform them of available buttons after a text message.
  • Visual cues like typing animations were translated into auditory feedback using `aria-live="polite"` for messages like "The agent is typing" and sound effects for message sending/receiving, providing a more comprehensive user experience.
  • The author realized that accessibility is not just for users with disabilities but enhances clarity and friendliness for all users.
  • The goal is to establish these accessibility improvements as a common pattern within the team, potentially by creating reusable utilities for focus management and timing.
  • The ultimate aim is to create services that users can confidently use even with their eyes closed.
